First off the show is in low definition which looks terrible.  Whats worse this "documentary" apparently did no fact checking, in the first episode on submarines they say the U.S. Ohio class ballistic nuclear submarine was the submarine featured in the movie The Hunt for Red October.  This is patently incorrect, the submarines featured in the movie are primarily the USSR's  ("Shark") (NATO reporting name: Typhoon) and the US's 688 Los Angeles class with the USSR's Shchuka (NATO reporting name "Akula") making a lesser appearance.  There was no Ohio class submarine in the movie.  I didn't watch any further.

I agree with other reviewers that while having an Australian perspective was interesting the numerous and blaring errors were just too much.  An example was the section on destroyers.  If the opening monolog had referenced WW ONE then it would have been correct but it referenced WWII; since the RN ASDIC had been developed in the interwar period the RN figured that they could detect and sink U-boots with easy - not correct.  The use of SURFACE ATTACK by German U-boots negated the ASDIC and it was not until the collaborative development and production of SONAR with RADAR plots (using the PPI screens) that the U-boots tactics became suicidal.

There were many other errors of similar nature scattered through out.  The section on the Harrier did not differentiate between the AV8-A (original British version) which made the pilot handle multiple tasks manually and the AV8-B (Americanized version) which automated many of the tasks for hovering.

Their was no mention of the disasterous political decision for the RN and subsequently the RAN to abandon large deck carriers (flying conventional aircraft) nor that the RN had any available carriers only because two carriers which were to be sold to India were available for conscription.  The loss of the container ship Atlantic Conveyor was a major blow because it contained the experimental USN flight deck kit which would have given the RN much more deck space for Harriers.

The Sea Power documentary series is great, they have tailored it so that the most novice civilian can understand military technology, they blend technology information with historical data. This explains why and how military technology evolves; in an editorial in a quarterly publication named Naval Proceedings, an author writes that, "naval regulations are written in blood" because they are written as a result of an event in which most often than not cost the lives of sailors.

I watched one episode featuring the Australian Navy. I was looking forward to seeing authentic imagery and learning facts I hadn't known before, but was disappointed. The part where they really lost me was when they started talking about the A-4, but were clearly showing video of the British Aerospace (BAE) Systems Hawke.

Then they showed some old footage of American A-4's and talked about how modern and capable the A-4 was before going on to say it had been retired from service years ago, replaced by the F/A-18 Hornet.

Overall the quality and substance of the documentary felt very low and was closer to something you'd expect from the news media rather than a full-fledged documentary.

I thoroughly enjoy military documentaries and always love to watch just to see if I can find some video or learn a piece of information I've never come across before. Even though this documentary was disappointing, there were a few good bits showing the Royal Australian Navy and New Zealand Navy underway. It's very interesting to see how crews from different nations interact and work together. It was also interesting seeing some footage of Australian submarines underway.

Overall, I don't think I'll watch many of the other videos in the series though as this one was just a little too boring.

Too bad, though I am thankful to anyone who endeavors to create documentaries on militaries as it feels like most of the content out there has been recycled over and over throughout the years. Nice to see new stuff from time to time.

I struggled through the first episode--Submarines--even though I was ready to quit after ten minutes.  Many errors and omissions.  Time on irrelevancies.  "Sea Power" with a major portion dedicated to the towing and setup as a museum an obsolete (actually as of the day it was launched!) British submarine in Australia.  Was this an Australian production?  If so, does this demonstrate what the Aussies knew about what happened in WWII submarine warfare?  Much coverage of the German U-Boat war (that failed) and no coverage of the U.S. submarine war--that succeeded--in the Pacific, where with only 2% of the USN's men and materiel, the submarine force sunk the equivalent of 90% of Japan's merchant fleet and one third of the Imperial Navy.

Actually, the narrator lost me about five minutes in when showing and talking about the Ohio class ballistic missile sub and explaining that it was featured in the novel and movie (actually I think he only mentioned the movie...maybe wasn't aware of the novel?) "The Hunt for Red October".  In fact, the U.S. sub in the movie was the Dallas, a Los Angeles class ATTACK submarine.  I suffered to the end of the episode hoping it would get better.  It didn't.

Would have given this series only one star, but looking at some of the archive footage was interesting. I watched the amphibious episode within the first 10 minute I heard two completely unfounded things it sounded like the announcer just made up off the top of his head. First he said the US Marine corps was created just before the start of World War Two. Second the announcer said that there was an amphibious assault on Afghanistan!!! It's a land locked country!!! I just shut it off google something for god sakes.

First off I am a retired 20 year veteran of the USN. I was an STGC which a chief sonar technician surface and I was reasonable for the maintenance and operation of the ships asw sensors, fire control, and weapons on FF which main mission was asw.. The information on subs is about as wrong as you can get. The classes of subs is totally upside up side down and omissions abound. If you are interested in learning about submarines look elsewhere.
